First Party Collection/Use.description: Universal Rules for Identifying First Party Collection/Use:
sentence_structures: "We collect [data type] directly from users through [method] on our website."
"Your user account information is used to personalize your experience on our platform."
"We may use customer data to send you marketing emails about our products and services."
negation_patterns: "We do not share your data with third parties."
"We will not use your information for any purpose other than [specified purpose]."
First Party Collection/Use.note: These rules are based on a limited dataset and may not be exhaustive. It's crucial to consider the specific context and legal requirements when determining whether data collection and use practices constitute first-party collection/use.

Third Party Sharing/Collection.description: Based on the provided analyses indicating all instances as "safe," it appears there are no clear universal rules for identifying Third Party Sharing/Collection in this context.

User Access Edit and Deletion.description: Universal Rules for Identifying User Access Edit and Deletion
key_phrases: Safe Access:  Indicates the action is permitted and doesn't pose a risk.
Authorized Modification:  Suggests the edit is within the user's permissions.
Controlled Deletion:  Implies a secure and regulated process for removing data.
Access Granted:  Confirms the user has the right to perform the action.
Permissioned Edit:  Highlights the user's explicit authorization for the change.
sentence_structures: Subject + Verb + Object + Prepositional Phrase:  "The user granted access to the document."
Subject + Verb + Adverbial Phrase:  "The deletion was performed safely."
Subject + Verb + Object + Clause:  "The system allows users to edit their profiles."
negation_patterns: "Not permitted" or "Unauthorized":  These phrases would indicate actions that are not safe and should be avoided.
User Access Edit and Deletion.note: These rules are based on the limited information provided.  A more comprehensive analysis would require a larger dataset and deeper understanding of the specific context.

Do Not Track.description: Universal Rules for Identifying "Do Not Track"
sentence_structures: "I want to Do Not Track my browsing activity."
"Please respect my Do Not Track preference."
"My browser is set to Do Not Track."
negation_patterns: "Do Not Track" is the primary phrase and negation is implied.
"Allow Tracking" or "Enable Tracking" would be used to express the opposite.

While these rules provide a starting point, the specific context and phrasing used to indicate "Do Not Track" can vary.  It's crucial to consider the broader context and user intent for accurate identification.

Policy Change.description: Universal Rules for Identifying Policy Change:
key_phrases: New legislation, policy proposal, regulatory change
sentence_structures: Subject + Verb (amend/modify/etc.) + Object (policy/law/regulation).
Example: The government will amend the existing environmental policy.
There will be a change in policy regarding [topic].
Example: There will be a change in policy regarding data privacy.
Effective [date], the new policy will come into effect.
Example: Effective January 1st, 2024, the new policy will come into effect.
negation_patterns: Not applicable, no change, status quo
Example: There will be no change to the current tax policy.
These are just potential starting points.
Context is crucial: The specific language used to denote policy change will vary greatly depending on the subject matter, industry, and jurisdiction.
Machine learning: For accurate identification, a machine learning model trained on a large dataset of policy documents would be more effective.

User Choice/Control.description: Universal Rules for Identifying User Choice/Control:
sentence_structures: The user can choose from a variety of options.
Users have the option to customize their settings.
Input your preferred settings here.
negation_patterns: The user is not allowed to change this setting.
There is no option to select a different language.
User Choice/Control.note: While these rules provide a general framework, context is crucial.  The specific wording and surrounding sentences will ultimately determine whether user choice and control are present.

Introductory/Generic.description: Universal Rules for Identifying Introductory/Generic Statements:
sentence_structures: Subject + Verb + Adverbial of Degree (e.g., generally, often) + Object/Clause:  Generally, cats are good hunters.
Introductory Phrase + Subject + Verb: In general, people enjoy spending time with friends.
Subject + Verb + Complement Clause (introducing a general statement): It is important to remember that everyone makes mistakes.
negation_patterns: Not always/never: While dogs are often loyal, they are not always friendly towards strangers.
Exceptions: Generally, birds can fly, but penguins are an exception.
Introductory/Generic.note: These rules are not exhaustive and there can be variations in language and context.
